awd_titl_txt: High-Accuracy Thermochemistry with Threshold and Imaging Photoelectron Photoion Coincidence Spectroscopy
awd_abstract_narration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms - A Program of the Division of Chemistry, Prof. Bálint Sztáray from the University of the Pacific, will characterize the thermochemistry of molecules and radicals that have combustion or atmospheric relevance. Using Photoelectron Photoion Coincidence Spectroscopy, significant improvements will be offered to three of the most important parameter sets in combustion and atmospheric models: accurate experimental thermochemical data, reaction rates, and energy distributions. The experiments will be conducted both on the lab-based instrument at the University of the Pacific, which will receive an upgrade of a new ion velocity map imaging setup, and on the Imaging Photoelectron Photoion Coincidence Spectroscopy endstation at the Swiss Light Source synchrotron. Combining experimental ion fragmentation and velocity distribution data with high-level quantum chemical calculations, advances will be offered in the understanding of statistical rate and energy distribution theories to improve the kinetics modeling tools used in combustion and atmospheric models.

Energy is arguably the most important physical quantity, affecting almost every aspect of physical, chemical and biological processes. Chemical changes in the structure of molecules are almost invariably accompanied by changes in the energy, determining which chemical reactions are possible. As the primary purpose of combustion processes is to extract energy from chemical systems, characterizing the energy content of the various molecules and fragments involved in combustion is the foundation on which predictive models can be built. Thermochemistry, the study of the role of energy in chemical processes, has gone through transformative changes in the last decade, partly due to advances in computational methods and party due to new holistic models in which energy changes in remotely related systems are connected in a complex web of energy relationships. Computational methods in the past few years have approached and even exceeded experimental accuracy and they need new and more accurate experimental data to be tested against. The experimental methods used in this research will provide some of the most accurate numbers on a wide variety of systems that are involved in combustion or atmospheric processes.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF-funded research focuses on the thermochemistry of molecules and radicals that have combustion or atmospheric relevance. The experimental technique that was used is Photoelectron Photoion Coincidence (PEPICO) Spectroscopy, a combination of Mass Spectrometry and Photoelectron Spectroscopy. With this, complex dissociation reaction mechanisms can be deduced and accurate experimental thermochemical data and dissociation rates can be determined. Some of the experiments were conducted on the lab-based instrument at the University of the Pacific and most of the studies were done on a more advanced instrument at the Swiss Light Source (SLS). As, during this work, a promising new use for PEPICO was theorized and then demonstrated, some of the experimental efforts and the scientific focus has gradually shifted towards the new idea of employing PEPICO to study gas-phase reaction mechanisms of unstable species with combustion, atmospheric, or astrochemical relevance.

Results of the research performed during the lifetime of this NSF grant have been disseminated in twelve published papers and through 10+ oral and about 15–20 poster presentations. Substantial progress has been made on studying dissociations and energetics of a variety of small organic species. Through collaborations, computer modeling tools have also been disseminated, which were used to analyze systems outside the primary focus of our original proposal, as well. Working closely with the Paul Scherrer Institute in Switzerland and Sandia National Lab in California, this project was leading the field both in terms of advanced PEPICO experiments (hardware), as well as data analysis (software).

Some of the most significant results can be organized whether the measurements allowed to explore accurate thermochemistry, reaction rates or pathways or complex mechanisms. With respect to accuracy, the studies on water represent the very best that PEPICO can offer. The protonation of this singularly important molecule is one of the most important chemical processes. In this project, its energetics has been measured by PEPICO and the published value represents a significant correction of the literature value of, while also reducing its uncertainty by more than an order of magnitude.

The field of high-accuracy thermochemistry has been going through a renaissance and the hereby measured thermochemical values provided reliable bond energies for systems of combustion, atmospheric, or synthetic interest and they entered key databases. For the smallest molecules, these measurements have provided benchmarks for theoretical chemistry, challenging theorists to carry out calculations with unprecedented accuracy.

A longstanding challenge in experimental gas phase physical chemistry is to find a selective detection method for neutral molecules that interrogates chemical reactions with high fidelity. In a recent letter, it has been demonstrated that PEPICO spectroscopy can offer the combined advantages of other methods. In these proof-of-concept experiments, performed on the existing imaging PEPICO endstation of the SLS, the superior information content of PEPICO detection was demonstrated and, based on these encouraging results, in collaboration with the Combustion Research Facility (CRF) of Sandia National Lab, a prototype experiment was designed and built. With this PEPICO spectroscopy could follow the rate of a gas-phase chemical reaction for the very first time and the new laser photolysis inlet system was shown to be useful to measure several key, elusive unstable chemical species. Using PEPICO to analyze reacting systems of combustion and atmospheric intermediates offers a huge step forward and has been called a game-changer in the gas-phase kinetics/combustion community. One of the main outcomes of this project was re-inventing the technique as a highly selective detection method and, in the future, flame, pyrolysis and even shock-tube experiments can benefit from the added selectivity and duty cycle of this technique and extend its utility to the broader scientific community.

These experiments all involves custom-built instruments and the graduate students learned unique design, fabrication and maintenance skills. These skills positioned them well on the job market helping to find employment with instrumental analytical companies after graduation. The main instrument has also been used in upper-division instrumental courses and students could tweak this custom apparatus in ways that are not possible with commercial instruments.
